characters: I/E. ROYAL ACADEMY OF MUSIC, FOYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELTON JOHN in a sequined and feathered catsuit storms alo a halo of coloured feathers and enormous stained-glass spectacles. He is a man with a purpose but looks like shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton sits dramatically in the seat and stares confrontationally at the circle of addicts. He sweats profusely.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: How long is this going to take?

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR
dialogues.text: That’s really up to you. You need to set your own pace..... Everybody stares. Elton is clearly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Right then! I know how this goes. My name is Elton John. And I’m an alcoholic. And a cocaine addict. And a sex addict. And a bulimic! I’m also a shopaholic who has problems with weed, prescription drugs and anger management. The group look at him incredulously. Elton blinks angrily behind his enormous glasses. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should talk about your childhood?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should talk about your hair!? Some of the group are shocked and some laugh. The counsel smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COUNSELOR
dialogues.text: What are your earliest memories? Cue: The frantic opening from ‘THE BITCH IS BACK’. Elton up and walks to the middle of the room and sings.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 2.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I was justified when I was five Raisin’ Cain, I spit in your eye Times are a changing now the poor get fat, But the fever’s gonna catch you when the bitch gets back, oh, oh, oh. The patients and counselor are dumbfounded as out of nowh a child (REGGIE), 6 years old, rides in through the doubl doors on a bike with stabilizers and circles Elton. The y Reggie stops and stares at Elton and joins in the song.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON/REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m a bitch, I’m a bitch oh, the bitch is back, stone cold sober as a matter of fact, I can bitch, I can bitch cause I’m better than you, It’s the way that I move, the things that I do oh. A shocked Elton tries to grab Reggie as he dumps his bike runs out the door. A singing Elton chases after him, the therapy group and counselor follow behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Reggie bursts through the doors and enters a 1950's London residential street. Reggie, walks down the middle the street followed by Elton and the rehab group. The milkman, postman and lollipop lady all wave to him. A bra band come marching down the street and they all smile and wave. People stream out of the houses and join in the gro dance. The rehab group, lead by Elton, follow and sing al

dialogues.speaker: ELTON/REGGIE
dialogues.text: Eat meat on a Friday, that’s all right. Even like steak on a Saturday night. I can bitch the best at your social do’s. I get high in the evening sniffing pots of glue, oh, oh oh. It becomes a dance number that Reggie conducts with the r group and the people in the street. Reggie turns into the driveway of a drab house, turns back to the rehab group looking over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m a bitch, I’m a bitch oh, the bitch is back. Stone cold sober as a matter of fact. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 3.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can bitch, I can bitch cause I’m better than you. It’s the way that I move, the things that I do oh.. Elton looks troubled. The music stops abruptly. SHEILA, his mum, comes out holding a mechanical sweeper.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Reggie! You’re late! I’ve thrown your dinner in the bin! Get inside. Reggie tucks in his shirt and follows his mum into the ho INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 4 An archetypal suburban scene. IVY, grandma, in the kitche works on a sewing machine. A depressed budgie lolls in it cage. Sheila attacks a carpet with the mechanical sweeper like she’s trying to break it. Reggie follows her around.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Is he back?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: What am I? Thin air?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure he’s actually coming home?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t get your hopes up. He’s very unreliable and very selfish.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: But will you send him to see me if I'm already in bed?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Reggie! Stop being a nuisance! I need to get this done before I go out. She picks him up and puts him on the piano stool. The rad plays: The Skater’s Waltz. As dust hangs in the sunlight, Reggie sways to the music looks at the piano keyboard. As it lilts on in the backgr Reggie tries a note - remarkably it is in tune.  White Shooting 4. Reggie plays the note again and then adds two more. Again they are exactly in tune. He looks around. No one pays attention: Reggie tries again and this time plays a whole section of melody and ends with a low note with his left hand. Bong! Suddenly the world seems to stop. The budgie stares froze its perch, boggle eyed. Ivy comes in from the Kitchen. Sh turns around to see what all the fuss is about.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Did I do something wrong? Ivy Bloody hell, Sheila. Maybe we should get him some lessons.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I'd love too, if it’d get him out from under my feet but we’re not made of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton takes off his feathered head-dress.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Mum always supported me. She knew I was very talented. Both my parents did. INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 6 Sheila paints her nails and gets ready to go out. Ivy sit front of the fire and reads a magazine. The doorbell ring Ivy looks up, Sheila looks pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie rushes out of his room and listens as Sheila goes the door. I/E. FRONT DOOR, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 8 The door opens to reveal STANLEY, Reggie’s dad, dressed immaculately in his RAF uniform. He gives a faint rueful smile to Sheila and Ivy.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 5.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: You've managed to drag yourself home then. Ivy I see the milkman’s back. Hello, Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: How are you, Ivy?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Like you care. Well, come on then! You're letting in a draught. He wipes his very shiny boots and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: You've put on weight.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: And you look shorter. How long you back?

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: I’ve got couple of weeks leave. Ivy Reggie’s not long gone to bed.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Pop up, say hello.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: I'll see him tomorrow. Any dinner left? Stanley walks off into the kitchen. INT. LANDING, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 9 In the shadows Reggie is sad and disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie runs down the street as fast as he can in his scho uniform. He passes all the other local kids playing footb

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Oi four eyes! You’re in goal. Reggie ignores them and keeps running.  11 12 White Shooting 6. INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 11 Reggie, enters home and stares in wonder at his father as takes a jazz record out of it’s sleeve, meticulously clea it with a velvet pad, places it carefully on the turn tab and it starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Dad, is it true you play the piano? I’m saving to get lessons.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: If you want to sit in here you'll have to stay quiet. I’m listening to my music. As Stanley listens to the record Reggie watches him for a moment then goes and gets a record from the shelf and pro presents it to his Dad.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I like this one, Dad, will you play it for me? He leaps up, snatching the record from Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: Who said you could touch those? Never, ever, touch my collection without asking. Stanley carefully puts the record back and turns to look Reggie. Reggie looks at his father then goes in for a hug Stanley doesn’t respond but looks uncomfortable and pushe him off.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be soft Reggie runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton talks to the counselor but is clearly agitated, ang and confrontational with her.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: He was always hugging me! It was fucking embarrassing. My dad was passionate about family and music. We'd talk for hours about jazz. I was lucky. I was actually a very happy child.  13 14 15 16 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 7. EXT. GARDEN, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 13 Reggie throws a tantrum and smashes plant pots with a cri bat at the bottom of the garden.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s not fair. I hate him. I wish I’d never been born. Shelia, all glammed up wanders down and watches Reggie. Reggie stops and looks at the destruction he’s caused. He looks at Shelia.

dialogues.speaker: SHELIA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Shelia lights a cigarette and puffs thoughtfully. INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 14 Reggie seated at the piano. His legs dangle over the edge the stool. A PIANO TEACHER is there and Shelia watches fo moment. She takes some slimming pills from her handbag, p a couple and then goes. Reggie learns his scales. INT. CORRIDOR, REGGIE’S HOUSE. NIGHT. 15 A slightly drunk Sheila, walks past Reggie’s room. She se light on and stops. She opens the door and sees Reggie reading music. Reggie looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: What are you still doing up?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Learning. I want to play a song for dad.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Your dad’s gone back to his unit. Go to sleep. Sheila turns off the light. INT. REGGIE'S BEDROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 16 The door closes. Reggie sits in the darkness. After a mom a torch comes on and Reggie slowly mimes playing the pian  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 8. As he becomes more animated the sound of Tchaikovsky Pian concerto No.1 accompanies him. He stands and points with his torch like a conductor to b in a string section. The shafts of the light wave over th room and we catch glimpses of the orchestra. We hear strings, brass and woodwind join - as Reggie, conducts. The whole orchestra plays. Suddenly the door op and the light goes on. Reggie freezes and looks up, terrified. It’s Ivy. She has 2 cakes. Ivy Take no notice. These will make you feel better. She kisses him and goes out. Reggie takes a bite of the c then raises his hands to start the orchestra again, as we to: INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 17 Reggie plays the Concerto effortlessly for real. As we pu out we see Reggie is now 12 years old. He finishes the pi with a flourish. The piano teacher smiles. INT. KITCHEN, REGGIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 18 Ivy irons Sheila’s dress. Sheila, her hair in curlers and her underwear, reads Vogue. Reggie is by the back door.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: The Royal Academy of Music!? (beat) Pass me those scissors. Reggie brings her the scissors. Sheila cuts out a pattern a skirt.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What d’ya think? She shows him the picture.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: The red’s nicer.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It’s only on Saturday's.  White Shooting 9.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Saturdays! I’ve things to do on the weekends. I can’t just drop everything. You can go on your own. Ivy smiles at Reggie. Ivy I’ll take you. Make sure you’re settled in.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mum. The immaculately dressed Stanley enters and takes in Shei There is tension and mistrust in the air.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: Where are you off too?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Don’t know. I haven’t decided yet but wherever it is I’m going to have fun. Something you old RAF types don’t do. Ivy Reg’s piano teacher thinks he’s good enough to get a scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: Really? Has he got that kind of talent?

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Course he has. But you’d know that if you took the slightest bit of interest in me and this family. Sheila goes.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. ROYAL ACADEMY OF MUSIC, FOYER
dialogues.text: Ivy stands next to a nervous Reggie, dwarfed by the dusty surroundings. A bearded student pushes past them with a double bass in a case. The place swarms with duffle coate students. Reggie looks around, awed and bewildered as the walk up a grand staircase.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Can we go home?  20 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 10. Ivy Home? There’s no going home! This is it now. This is your life. You have to get over this silly shyness.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: But mum says we can’t... Ivy Life gives you very few chances, Reggie. This is one of yours. Show them you’re as good as they are. Better! Be number one. Everyone’s scared in the beginning. Play at being confident. You can do that can’t you?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Easy. Ivy Good. So go on then. Ivy gives him some change.

dialogues.speaker: IVY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s enough for a bag of chips and your bus fare home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie wanders into the room transfixed by the music. HEL PIENA plays a piece by Mozart unaware that he is there. S sees him and stops.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: Reginald Dwight?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: Did you bring something to play?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know I had to.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: Is there anything you could show me so I can get a sense of where you are up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 White Shooting 11. He sits down, prepares, then plays the opening chord. One note is out. He blushes. He plays it again, this time correctly, then plays the Mozart piece note perfect, then stopping mid-phase exactly where she left off.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why have you stopped?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: That’s as far as you got. Helen looks impressed that Reggie has played it by ear. H beams a cheeky smile, but Helen does not smile back.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: You might have a good memory but you have an awful lot of work to do. Keep you wrists and back straight and start again. His smile drops, he realises this is going to be hard wor Helen smiles, she knows she has a real talent on her hand INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 21 Stanley, Sheila, Ivy and Reggie all sit at the table in formal silence. A roast chicken on the table. Sheila, bored and distracted wants be else where. Reggie starts to tap out his piano scales and crunches on a stic celery.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: Hands off the table, Reginald. And stop making all that noise. Sheila scoffs and looks at Reggie like ‘I told you’. An unsure Reggie slowly withdraws his hands. Stanley proceed carve.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Did you know Mozart wrote his first piece of music at the age of 5? Reggie is served last with a very small amount. They eat silence. Sheila pushes her food around the plate. Reggie knows that his family doesn’t work. Ivy sneaks Reggie a p of chicken and winks at him. The intro music starts: ‘I W LOVE’. Stanley gets up from the table and lights his pipe looks out of the window.  22 White Shooting 12.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want love, but it’s impossible. A man like him, so irresponsible. A man like him is dead in places.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: Other men feel liberated. I can’t love, shot full of holes. Don’t feel nothing, I just feel cold. Don’t feel nothing..

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: «--just old scars. Toughening up around my heart. I want love on my own terms. After everything I’ve learned. Ivy Me, I carry too much baggage. Oh god I’ve seen so much traffic. But I want love...

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: .--just a different kind.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I want love..

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY
dialogues.text: .-won’t break me down.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Won’t brick me up, won’t fence me in.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I want a love, that’ll mean something.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: That’s the love I want, I want love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheila fumbles in a car with FRED who wears a draped jack and has a D.A. hair style. He tries to get her buttons Suddenly he stops, shocked. Sheila looks round and sees Reggie by the car window looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Mum! ?  23 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 13. She winds the window down.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Reggie, what are you doing here? * Snooping around? * Fred breaks the embarrassment and presents his hand to th stunned Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, son. I’ve heard a lot about you. Reggie stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name’s Fred. I’m a friend of your mum’s. Reggie looks at Sheila with tears in his eyes then turns runs.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Reggie! INT. REGGIE'S BEDROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 23 Reggie sits on his bed. Stanley shouts at Sheila. He is furious and loud.

dialogues.speaker: STANLEY, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Too bloody right I’1l go! Good! I’m sick of the sight of you. I puta roof over your head. You’ve wanted for nothing. And this builder is what you want now, is he? Got money has he? You love a pound note. You'd drop your knickers for a quid. You self centered, vain, tramp. + eH HH

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Shut up you pig! Get out, just go. Reggie closes his eyes and puts his hands over his ears t drown out the shouting. He starts singing. ‘La, la, la, l la, la...’ as in the start of CROCODILE ROCK.’ Heavy footsteps can be heard on the stairs and along the hallway. Reggie’s door is ajar. He watches the shadow of dad outside his room on the wall. Reggie hopes his Dad wi come in. Stanley turns, hesitates. He’s in two minds. The decides against it and goes down the stairs.  24 White Shooting 14. The front door slams. Close on Reggie’s heartbreak and confusion. He goes to his bedroom window and watches his walk off down the street with his suitcase. He doesn’t lo back. Reggie sits on his bed and starts to cry. Ivy comes and sits in a chair by the window.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: He didn’t give me a hug goodbye? Ivy He’s no good at showing affection.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I wish I was somebody else. It’s dark and she lights a cigarette. Ivy I heard a song on the radio today I thought you’d like. Quietly taps her nails on the chair and she starts to gen sing ‘HEARTBREAK HOTEL’.

dialogues.speaker: IVY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since my baby left me. I’ve had a new place to dwell. It’s down on the end of a lonely street. Heartbreak Hotel. My baby’s so lonely my baby’s lonely I could die. Reggie listens. Slowly he stops crying.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Who sings it? She sings on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton has now removed more of his costume and sits in his vest with just the bottom half of his feather suit on. Th rest lies in a crumpled heap on the floor. He looks defla and the anger is gone. His head and voice are low and he cries. His hands shake.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: How the fuck do you think I felt!? I was a kid. Heartbroken. People don’t care though, do they? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 15.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, I'd discovered records and rock'n'roll. That was all I cared about.

dialogues.speaker: U.S TV PRESENTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now ladies and gentlemen a rising star of Rock and Roll, all the way from Memphis Tennessee, please welcome Elvis Presley. INT. BACK ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 25 We cut into a T.V. Elvis’ first appearance on an American T.V. Show. Reggie and Ivy sit on the sofa mesmerized by E as he sings ‘Blue Suede Shoes’. Reggie’s eyes are lit up excitement. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie takes out an exercise book. It is a diary with sev columns of lists. There is a list of “Tunes Learnt” and n another one “Records to purchase” - He writes carefully i the ‘Elvis Presley’ column - ‘Blue Suede Shoes’. * Fred and Sheila come in from shopping. Sheila turns down t.v.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I got you this while I was out. I know you like him. Sheila pulls out Elvis album from a bag. Reggie can’t bel it.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s quite a dish. She holds up the cover of the record and they all gaze at fantastic picture of Elvis in all his glory. Ivy Ooo. I would.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Mum!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mum. It’s fantastic. Reggie slowly takes the record. Transfixed. It is obvious that it is in very safe hands with Reggie.  26 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 16.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Be careful with it.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: So - are you serious about wanting to be a rock’n’roller?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Course.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Okay, we should get you the proper hair cut then.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Can I get it cut like Elvis?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Course you can.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Enjoy it while it lasts. You’re like my side of the family. You'll be bald as an egg by the time you're twenty. Reggie looks shocked and dismayed. Ivy shakes her head. Sheila exits with the shopping. Ivy And a jacket.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Eh? Ivy He’1l need a proper jacket. Ivy holds up the record with Elvis on the front.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: And shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie is at orchestra rehearsals now dressed in his new shoes, jacket and hair cut. The rest of the kids are all dressed a lot more square. A happy Reggie sticks out like sore thumb. A concerned Helen Piena looks at him.  27 28 White Shooting 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A home-made sign in the window say: “Tonight: All meat ra plus Reginald Dwight on piano”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run down hotel bar. A seedy BARMAN talks into the mic t half empty pub. Sheila, Fred and Ivy are all there with a drink. An old upright piano is on the small stage. A man holds up a bag of meat above his head to a small cheer.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations to Dave, he wins four pork chops, half a pound of prime mince and a string of sausages. Right, now Sheila and Fred's boy is going to play us a couple of songs on the piano so give him a warm welcome cos he’s only 12 and get’s a bit shy. Reggie Dwight. Reggie wears his quiff on full attention. He’s decidedly nervous as he walks onto the little stage and sits at the piano. Ivy signals her encouragement. There is an instant feedback through the mic. This gets everybody’s attention

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello. Reggie starts to play ‘STREETS OF LAREDO’. No one is impressed. A bloke puts a pint down on top of the piano a continues to talk loudly to his friend. Reggie is intimid and stops. He looks at Ivy who winks at him and mouths. Ivy Play that one I like.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You can’t put that on there.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It‘ll get knocked off. Reggie hits the first chord of ‘SATURDAY NIGHT'S ALRIGHT FIGHTING)’.  29 White Shooting 18.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “It’s getting late have you seen my mates...” As somebody turns to watch Reggie they knock over a woman beer and it spills down the front of a big bloke. He turn and pushes the wrong person which starts a small shoving match, and a fight breaks out. Someone bumps into Fred an turns round and whacks them then turns back to Sheila and puts his arm around her as if nothing has happened. Reggi watches as he plays and gets excited by the atmosphere. A the fight builds so does his playing and energy. He grows into a solid and exciting performer and his singing start push the energy of the fight. People fly across the room, glasses are smashed, chairs are thrown. Reggie sings on.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Ma tell me when the boys get back here. It’s seven o’clock and I want to rock. Wanna get a belly full of beer” Reggie ducks as a chair flies over the piano. Sheila, Fre and Ivy are in the middle of the chaos with their gin and tonics and still smile encouragingly at Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “My old man’s drunker than a barrel full of monkey’s. And my old lady she don’t care. My sister looks cute in her braces and her boots. A handful of grease in her hair” Two men, now on top of the piano, fight and Ivy hits them with her handbag. Reggie has to dive this way and that to avoid being hit but plays without missing a beat.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “So don’t give us none of your aggravation. We’ve had it with yer discipline. Saturday night’s alright for fighting. Get a little action in”. Suddenly someone has a chair and is about to crash it dow onto the piano when Reggie leaps out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie emerges from the pub in the middle of an ally whic runs down. He come out in the street and jumps over the t of cars - he boots someone who tries to attack him, whils of course, singing in perfect time.  30 31 White Shooting 19.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: “Get about as oiled as a diesel train. Gonna set this dance alight. Cause Saturday night’s alright for fightin’. Saturday night’s alright, alright, alright”. Reggie escapes by climbing through a hole in a wooden fen REGGIE is now seventeen years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie comes out into a huge fun fair with big bright lig and fast moving action. The bumper cars are close by and different gangs hang out here. Teddy boys, rockers, mods, Beatniks, Jamaicans, Indians, mums and dads with their ki All walks of British 60’s life. Reggie runs and ducks thr the legs of the bigger kids as they come together and car on the fight and dance. The bumper cars are packed with people and Reggie laughs as he hangs on to one of the car

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: “We're packed pretty tight in here tonight. I’m looking for a dolly who’ll see me right. I may use a little muscle to get what I need. I sink a little drink and shout she’s with me..” Reggie jumps off and runs and ducks through another hole the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie runs along the street and a gang of mods on scoote come towards him. He turns and goes the other way as the sing:

dialogues.speaker: MODS
dialogues.text: “A couple of sounds that we really like. Are the sound of a switchblade and a motorbike. We’re a juvenile product of the working class. Who’s best friend floats in the bottom of a glass”. Reggie flies out of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: “So don’t give us none of your aggravation. We’ve had it with yer discipline”.  32 33 White Shooting 20. Reggie sees the brightly lit pub and dives back in throug the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie dives across the bar and lands on the piano stool plays on. He has a band backing him called ‘Bluesology’ a dressed identically. Slim fitted, dark clothes and hush puppies. The pub is half full. Sheila, Fred and Ivy are t and politely clap.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: “Saturday night’s alright for fightin’. Get a little action in. Saturday! Saturday! Saturday! Saturday! Saturday! Saturday night’s alright.” The number finishes with a flourish. Everyone cheers. Reg beams back at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie and the band BOBBY, CYRIL and ELTON DEAN pack up. tall thin man leans against a wall and smokes. DAVE GODIN

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Good show tonight boys. You look like you know how to enjoy yourselves. How would you like to make two quid a week? Each! Elton Dean whistles.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON DEAN
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Dave Godin, promoter of the soul music review. I’ve got 3 new American acts doing a tour of England and they all need back up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We’re not a backing band!

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What’s soul music?

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Music for people who feel it in their heart. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 21.

dialogues.speaker: GODIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What I’m looking for is a band that have got music running through their souls. It’s about pain and love and heartbreak.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Forget all this Rock n Roll stuff. Wilson and the Twilights. The Bluebells. The sound of the future. Your future.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON DEAN
dialogues.text: Why don’t they have their own band?

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Enough talk! You’re obviously tough negotiators. Three pounds a week plus room and board. Beat. Godin hands Reggie his card and smiles enigmaticall

dialogues.speaker: GODIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think about it. I’1l need to know * by tomorrow lunch time. It’s six * months. So if you’re up for it * swing by the office, pick up the records. You’1ll have a week to * learn twenty songs. Reggie takes the card but a worrying thought comes over Reggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie walks along and looks unsure of himself. Other students come and go and some say hello. He nods back but distracted. He stops outside a door, paces for a bit then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie sits next to Helen Piena at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: Why are you so distracted, Reg? The ‘Puccini’ recital is next week. Being an accompanist is very * important and you’re obviously not * practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 22.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m not going to be able to do the recital. My bands been offered six months touring.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: You're throwing away all your hard work to dedicate your time to playing rock and roll in dirty pubs? Do you think that’s a good use of your talent?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to just play dead people’s music.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, if Puccini were alive today, he’d be playing rock'n'roll.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: You've got a great future here. The Royal Philharmonic is a very real possibility for you. Helen Piena plays the intro Nessun Dorma.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I need to do this. I love rock‘n’roll...

dialogues.speaker: HELEN PIENA
dialogues.text: Passion is important, Reggie but think it through. If you give up your place here you won’t be able to just walk back in when things don’t work out. Can you make any money playing this kind of music? There’s no stability in it. I like rock'n'roll to but I wouldn’t gamble my whole future on it. I can’t allow it. Helen plays ‘Nessun Dorma’ as Reggie gets up and walks ou She doesn’t look back but knows he is gone. INT. REGGIE’S BEDROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE 35A Reggie enters with a stack of records and throws them on bed and sits.  36 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 22a. There is a shelf in the room that has a few records on. Reggie puts the new disks on the shelf. He takes one and reverentially puts it on his record player. Intro music starts for ‘BREAKING DOWN THE WALLS OF HEARTA by THE BLUEBELLS. The song plays over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie carries his electric keyboards, the rest of the ba load equipment into a van. Godin smokes and the boys are excited as they get in the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 38 39 40 4l 42 43 White Shooting 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage - as ‘BREAKING DOWN THE WALLS OF HEARTACHE’ carri on: WILSON out front singing like a pro. Reggie plays some gr organ and looks at Wilson doing his thing and the crowd lapping it up. He’s a master at work. Reggie watches his every move, loving it and learning. Wilson is replaced by another great, DIANA and the BLUEBELLS all in beautiful t fitting gold dresses. Again Reggie watches in awe from be the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie and the rest of the band are crammed in at the bac They are happy and the energy is high. The laugh and smok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie on stage with the band. The TWILIGHTS sing and dan Reggie is at the back but he and the band all enjoy playi One of the singers, RICHARD smiles and winks at Reggie an smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corridor leading to the stage, Reggie passes Wilso dressing room and sees through the door. Wilson is being injected with heroin in his arm by his girlfriend. Wilson sees Reggie, smiles and nods at him. INT. STAGE - NIGHT Al On stage Reggie plays while he watches Wilson sing. He wo hard and sweat runs down his face and back. His shirt is soaked through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie packs away his organ as the other guys are surroun by dolly birds. Richard takes off his shirt and Reggie st at him. Richard catches him looking and holds Reggie’s ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie and the guys are all dressed differently and now h more shinny suits on.  44 45 46 47 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 24. They smoke and drink and are growing up fast. Bobby hands some pills which they all take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all in different costumes. The Bluebells sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie waits to go on. Richard comes up to him and they w The Bluebells perform for a bit. As the girls finish Rich turns to Reggie and suddenly kisses him on the lips on qu a sensual way.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Have a good show. Reggie is in shock by the thrill he has just experienced.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Richard laughs and walks out on stage. INT. REGGIE'S BEDROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - NIGHT 46 Reggie puts some records on the shelves which are much fuller. He flops down on his bed and stares at the ceilin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie and Wilson sit next to each other nursing drinks. other American acts, Godin and the rest of Bluesology dri and laugh with girls they’ve picked up.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What’s up, Reggie? Reggie watches them and broods.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: How does a fat boy with glasses from Pinner, called Reggie Dwight get to be a soul man?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Write some songs.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Easier said than done.  48 49 50 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 25.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Of course it is. Every song I write is part of me. What’s in your heart when you play?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Dunno - everything. It’s where I feel I’m not alone.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: There you go. Real poetic, kid. Set that to music. Wilson considers Reggie for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm a skinny, black, kid from Detroit who’s real name is Rodney Jones. I played roadside joints for ten years before I realised what I had to do.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: What? Change your name?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Not just your name. You have to kill the person you’re born to be in order become the person you want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson is doing his show. Reggie is once again at the bac but watches closely. The backing singers spin round and a they do Richard makes eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The transit van drive down the motorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they bump along the motorway a dejected Reggie looks a the band and the cramped conditions. Cyril smokes and loo untroubled as he pisses into a milk bottle and Bobby drin beer. Reggie picks up the NME and looks at the back pages spots something then rips out an ad. Cyril’s piss over fl and runs down the middle of the van getting on Reggie’s brothel creepers.  Yellow Rev. (10/24/18) White Shooting 26.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Aw fucking hell, Cyril. Cyril laughs. Reggie broods and rereads the ad in his han

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oi, Elton. Elton Dean looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON DEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to change my name. I’m thinking of calling myself Elton Dean.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON DEAN
dialogues.text: But that’s my name.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I know. What d’ya think?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON DEAN
dialogues.text: I think, fuck off! The other two laugh at Reggie who goes back to his ad. Dick James MUSIC PUBLISHING: Wants Talent. Artistes/ Composers/ singers/ Musicians. Call or write to RAY WILLIAMS. Denmark St. London. Tel. Mayfair 7362

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton smiles to himself at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: To be honest, I couldn’t stand being at the back any more. After just six weeks I was looking for my way out. You know what they say, “Hell is for other people”. I wasn’t cut out for sharing the back of an old van with people who didn’t care about their futures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH HH HH  51 52 Yellow Rev. (10/24/18) White Shooting 26A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reggie, dressed more flamboyantly than usual, walks down Denmark Street - London’s Tin Pan Alley - with it’s music publishers and guitar shops. He stops at a doorway. DJ Mu Publishing. He checks the address from an ad in the NME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In reception a Mary Quant type receptionist, MARY is at t desk. Reg tries to look very cool and important.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Can I help you?  White Shooting 27.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’ve come to see Mr. Williams. About the ‘Talent wanted’ ad.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Reginald Dwight. Mary girl laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Reginald!?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah! What?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: That’s my grandad’s name. Reggie blushes as Mary smirks and picks up the phone. INT. RAY WILLIAM’S OFFICE - DAY 53 Reggie stands and looks at the pictures of The Beatles. G records etc. Ray Williams a blonde Adonis of 21, has his on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’ve been gigging for years now.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Piano players I’ve got. Ten a penny, mate.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I sing too.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What sort of stuff?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: Anything, rock, soul, country and western. Reggie sits at the piano and plays the opening notes of ‘Streets of Laredo’.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Fucking hell! I’m going to shoot the next piano player who sings ‘Streets of Laredo’.  White Shooting 28. Reggie’s hands hover over the piano keys.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: I’ve written songs too. I’m good at tunes but I just haven’t figured out what to write about yet. Reggie plays the opening chords to ‘Candle In The Wind’.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: That’s good. What’s that called?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: It hasn't got a title. I just made it up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: What did you say your name was?

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: ..-Elton...

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Elton what? Reggie looks at a picture on the wall of The Beatles.

dialogues.speaker: REGGIE
dialogues.text: John? *From here on REGGIE will now be ELTON*

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Alright, Elton John the piano player. Leave your details with Mary at reception.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Give me a chance Mr. Williams. I’1l do anything. Ray sees a pile of envelopes on his desk and grabs two or three but then throws one at random to Elton.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Tell you what. See if there’s anything interesting in this and set it to music. It sails through the air. Everything slows down, music pl and a light hits the envelope as it flies majestically to Elton’s hands.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 29.

dialogues.speaker: RAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton pours over the pile of handwritten lyrics: The year the Teddy Bear, The Swan Queen of Laughing Lake, Tartan Coloured Lady and A Dandelion Dies in the Wind. He finds covering letter. He sees the name and address: “Bernie Taupin, Matkin Farm, Owmby-by-Spital, Lincolnshire”. Elton looks at his watch. He wears a Sixties t-shirt, a f jacket, tight pants and his hair is long. He has a cup of and watches expectantly as the straight laced people come go. A waitress comes and puts another tea in front of Elt

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: We close soon. * Then through the door comes a good looking young man who caries a copy of NME. From the way he’s dressed it’s obvi that he’s a country boy. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Bernie Taupin?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You must be Elton? * Bernie smiles and Elton is instantly smitten.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Actually, that’s my stage name. A nervous Bernie is impressed by this cool Londoner.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You can tell me your real name when we get to know each other better. Elton and Bernie sit opposite each other. A beat. *

dialogues.speaker: ELTON BERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was thinking... Have you ever been... *

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. *

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: No, after you. * They both smile. *  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 29A.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I like your lyrics.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Cheers. The tape you sent me is great. Do you write a lot?  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 30.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I’m on tour at the moment so I don’t get as much time as I'd like.. Bernie sees that there is a page mixed in with the lyrics sent and tries to take it back.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, that shouldn’t be in there. I sent that by mistake. Elton pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: No, that’s really good. I wrote a tune to this one. It just flowed out when I read it.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Skyline Pigeon?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I could hear the whole tune in my head. Everything was there and I could see all the notes and I had to get it out. My fingers couldn’t work fast enough to keep up with my brain... Bernie smiles and Elton blushes.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you ever get that?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Not really, no. But I could write some more if you’d like and, you know send them to you.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: My real name is Reg Dwight.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Cool. Sounds like a cowboy’s name. All I ever wanted to do was to be a cowboy. Do you like Country and Western, Reg? Have you ever heard ‘Streets of Laredo’ by Marty Robbins? Elton sings. +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 30A.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: As I walked out on the streets of Laredo. As I walked out on Laredo one day.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I spied a poor cowboy wrapped in white linen, wrapped in white linen as cold as the clay.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON/BERNIE
dialogues.text: "I can see by your outfit that you are a cowboy." These words he did say as I boldly walked by.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Come an' sit down beside me an' hear my sad story.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 31.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I'm shot in the breast an' I know I must die. They both smile and the song segways from ‘Streets of Lar into ‘Skyline Pigeon’. Elton knows he’s met a soul mate. Bernie and Elton talk m and more animatedly as the song carries on. Elton is clea blown away by Bernie. They talk and drink cups of tea unt they are thrown out when the cafe closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie walk through London as the city goes to sleep and look at the window displays at all the things t don’t have but plan to one day buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on a bench under a street light and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk, talk and laugh more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie part ways. They shake hands and Elton go in the cafe and Bernie walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his desk Bernie writes on an envelope. It is addressed ‘Reg’. He pulls out some pages from his note book, folds and puts them inside. 58 INT. REGGIE’S HOUSE - DAY 58 Elton sits at the piano surrounded by scraps of paper, letters and notes. Fred comes in with some post and hands Bernie’s letter. He opens it and puts Bernie lyrics on th piano and starts to compose.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 31A. 59 INT. RAY WILLIAM’S OFFICE - DAY 59 DICK JAMES a large 60 year old bald man smokes a cigar an sits at Ray’s desk with his feet up. He looks at Elton, Bernie and Ray. Elton at a piano finishes singing ‘Skylin pigeon’.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Fly away, skyline pigeon fly Towards the dreams. You've left so very, so very far behind.  White Shooting

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to be impressed?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: It’s catchy, Dick. These guys are special. I’ve got an instinct for these things.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Alright, don’t break your neck sucking your own cock. Dick walks round to the front of the desk, sits on stares at them. Dick looks at Elton then at Bernie them up.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe we should put these two into a little beat combo. They write, they sing, blah, blah. He’s the good looking one. Make him the singer. Elton is hurt and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Hold on, I’m tone deaf. We write together but Elton sings the songs. Dick looks at Ray and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: No offense but he’s not exactly the look kids are going crazy for. He’s a back room boy.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: They're writing a lot of good tunes, Dick.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Okay tiger. Are you flat mates?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: We live with our mum’s. I write the lyrics, send them to Elton and he adds the music.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Whoever heard of song writers not living and working together. Lennon and McCartney are inseparable. 32. it and and sizes  60 61 White Shooting 33. Elton looks at Bernie who shrugs. Dick picks up the music one of their songs and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: How many songs have you got?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Loads. More than thirty!?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Play one. Elton plays and sings ‘Daniel’

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Depressing. Another one. Elton tries again with ‘ Philadelphia Freedom’

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck’s that about!? ‘That’s Why They Call It The Blues’

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you taking the piss? Elton plays ‘Sad Songs’.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright! I’ve heard enough. Sounds like 99% of them are shit. It’s the 1% I’m interested in. Ray says you’re an investment but he knows fuck all. You’re both a couple of pricks as far as I can tell so quit that backing band nonsense, find a place to work together and write me tunes that gray haired old tramps will whistle in the street. You never know, one day you might have enough for an album. Do that and I‘1l put you on ten quid a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirty, well used 1960’s farm Land Rover with a canvas b drives down a residential street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie drives and Elton looks worried.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 34.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Why is this suddenly a problem? It’s rent free.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: So is my mum’s. It’s alright for you, it’s me she fancies for some strange reason.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: She was just being friendly. Anyway she’s a good looking bird.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: You go out with her then! She kept stroking my hair. It made me feel uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Fucking hell, Elton! Not your hair again! Last week you were all up for moving in.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: That was before I met her.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: We need to be closer to the center of town. Soho, not fucking Pinner. Elton fumes in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Land Rover has parked in front of a very run down terraced house. The street is lively with many people and kids about. Reggae music plays from a window somewhere. E and Bernie carry boxes of belongings up to the front door ARABELLA with two small dogs on her lap sits on the steps next to CLINT, a rasta and ARTHUR a very small bloke, smo a big joint.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Ah, my wonderful new lodgers. They're struggling rock stars. Arabella kisses Elton.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE, (TO ARTHUR)
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Bernie.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 35.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Whoever heard of a rock star called, Bernie?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Watch it, mate. Arthur stands up. As he’s on the top step he comes eye to with Elton and they square up to each other.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah? You going to do something about it?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I will if I have too. Clint laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CLINT
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, Arthur. Arabella gets up and leads Elton and Bernie inside. *

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: (To Elton) I was just telling Clint about the time I got arrested in Afghanistan for smoking pot outside of a Mosque. They were very understanding at the police station though. You two are going to love this place. I’ve got a real, Indian, Buddhist monk living next door, from Liverpool. INT. ARABELLA’S FLAT HALLWAY, ALL SAINTS ROAD - DAY 63 * Arabella shows them around the flat. The walls are covere with her shit art work, easels, paints, and a potters whe clutter the hallway. Think everything that was wrong abou the 60’s and this place should be full of it. Arabella sh them a room with just a single bed and a lot of junk art.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: This is your room. Some of my 2nd year course work is still in there and Clint’s borrowed the other mattress but we'll get it sorted out soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I can go on the sofa.  64 Blue Rev.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. You can bunk in with me. I have a huge bed. Elton looks angry at Bernie who shrugs his shoulders. Arabella grabs Elton by the hand and leads them into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’ll be like an ashram in India. Have you ever been to Goa? We should hitch hike there this summer.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I think I’d be happier on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Let’s celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arabella pops some champagne and pours it into mugs.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Here’s to us. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s get some music on.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Oh god. You can’t make loud noise in the flat. Livy has sensitive ears. Elton looks in horror at Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Livy the dog? We have to be able to play music. That’s why we moved in here.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be a nuisance. Come on, time for you to see our room. You can show me your intricate finger work. Arabella smiles a lascivious smile. She grabs Elton by hi collar and pulls him towards the bedroom. (07/31/18) White Shooting 36. 64  65 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 37.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: But it’s only six o’clock. Elton looks back in horror as Bernie is left with the champagne. Livy licks Bernie’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie are having a drink after the show. They deep in conversation. Wilson, Richard, Godin and a few of other Americans are at the next table. They are clearly talking about Elton and Bernie. They know each other well and the friendship between them all is warm and good natu Wilson looks over.

dialogues.speaker: GODIN
dialogues.text: Two weeks to go Reggie, you gonna miss us? Elton smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Sure. I'll be writing to you every five days. And the name’s Elton.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What’s your plans now, Elton?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Not too sure. We’ve written a lot of songs. Enough for an album.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: He’s probably going to get married too. All the guys laugh and give each other a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Arabella wants to get married.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: What about rock and roll? What about hot chicks? And cocaine orgies? What about fame and fortune.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What about the fact you’re a fag?  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 38.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're little friend is a homosexual. A worried Elton looks at Bernie who is shocked and a bit confused.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I’ve got a girlfriend. Wilson smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: When’s that ever stopped anybody? The penny drops for Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Are you? Elton is scared. Caught.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Does it matter? Bernie shrugs and laughs a little.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Not to me it doesn’t. Relieved Elton smiles at his friend.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it might do to Arabella.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Oh fuck. They both drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie are completely “shitfaced”. They stagger the door trying not to laugh too loud.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Ssssssshhhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Ssssssshhhhhhh!  67 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 39. Elton holds the key but falls over the bin. Bernie tries help Elton up but Elton pulls him down. They are laughing till suddenly a wave of clarity comes over Elton.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What am I going to do, Bernie? Bernie stops laughing and looks in Elton’s eyes. Elton hiccups again and breaks the mood.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You're going to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: It’ll break her heart.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure she has one. They burst into hysterics again. Suddenly the window open Arabella is in her nightdress. Both Bernie and Elton sit like two schoolboys.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Will you keep the noise down! You’1l wake the whole bloody street. Elton looks in despair at Bernie as Arabella slams the wi shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie are on the roof that over looks the city with a bottle of champagne. Their little party not over. Elton dangles his feet over the edge. Bernie is up, drunk animated.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about!? There’s so much we’ve got to do. Worlds to conquer. They’re great fucking songs! People keep asking who's singing the demos. You have got an amazing voice, Reg. It’s what I hear when I write. Something special happens when you sing our songs. Bernie sits next to Elton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 69 White Shooting 40.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: You've had too much to drink. You heard what Dick thinks. He said my hands are like midget boxers.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Fuck what Dick thinks. It’s time for you to be out front.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I’m not an artist.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Yes you are. Elton looks at Bernie then puts a hand on his knee. In th drunken state there is a moment of tenderness and friends between them. Bernie puts his hand on Elton’s knee. Elton leans in for a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Reg, I love you mate, but I’m sorry that’s never gonna happen. Elton takes his hand away. INT. BERNIE’S ROOM, ALL SAINTS ROAD - MORNING 68 Bernie sits on his bed writing. After a moment he stops a sniffs the air. INT. KITCHEN, ALL SAINTS ROAD —- MORNING 69 Bernie’s POV: Elton is lying on the floor with his head i the gas oven, on a pillow, with the gas on. The window is wide open.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Go away. I’m trying to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: (of the pillow) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to hurt my head.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: But the window’s open.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 41.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I know, it absolutely stinks. Bernie turns off the gas.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: What about our joint publishing deal?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: It’s alright, I’ve left everything to you. Bernie picks up a will scribbled in biro as Livy runs in starts licking Elton’s face.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Even the Bob Dylan albums? Arabella appears at the door

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: What are you doing

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: He’s going to kill himself.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Oh for godsake, what about the wedding? Elton sits up bumping his head.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: It’s all off. I’m never going to marry you. I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: But I’ve sent the invitations to the printers. And I’m pregnant with your baby.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. We’ve never even had sex properly.

dialogues.speaker: ARABELLA
dialogues.text: Haven’t we? Yes we have!

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: We haven’t got a proper relationship at all. I wouldn't marry you if you were the last person on earth.  70

dialogues.speaker: TOA
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (10/24/18) White Shooting 42. CLOSE UP on the shocked and horrified Arabella. Then, lik dam bursting she lets out a scream of rage. The whole hou seems to shake. Elton looks at Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie are throwing bags in the back of the Lan Rover as quick as they can. The boxes of records and suitcases are already loaded. Arabella can be heard screa and shouting from the house. A few neighbors are hanging and watching. Elton goes to run back in.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Come on. Where you going now?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: My keyboards are still in there! Suddenly Elton’s electric piano comes flying out the wind and smashes on the road.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: She's killed my piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton and Bernie sit in the car parked at the side of the road. Bernie is trying to sort through the lyrics and pap that Arabella threw out. They are in the middle of a row.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: You can write anywhere but it was my keyboards that got destroyed! We're not that desperate!

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Yes, we are! We don’t have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: We can live in the car until we find something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71 72 Yellow Rev. (10/24/18) White Shooting 42A.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Are you mad? There’s no fucking piano in the car! How are we supposed to work?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I’m not doing it! She’s a fucking nightmare. You’re always going on about how we need space to create. She'll eat up your space ina fucking heart beat with her craziness. We’1ll get nothing done and go mad in the process. You can go live there but I'll be fucked if I am. EXT. REGGIE’S HOUSE - EVENING 71 Sheila opens the door to a bedraggled Elton and Bernie, t stand with their things.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I knew you'd be back. You’1l have to pay rent. I’m not made of money. INT. KITCHEN, REGGIE’S HOUSE - MORNING 72 Bernie, in his dressing gown, scribbles amongst the debri a full English breakfast. Fred reads the paper. A listles Elton wanders in and sits. Sheila puts a fresh pot of tea the table.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Get dressed, Reggie +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Elton.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: Whatever you're calling yourself, I‘’1l not have you moping around here all day.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: We're song writing.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Looks like it’s going well. 43. Bernie hands Elton a piece of paper which he starts to re

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: (to himself) There’s egg on this. Bernie closely watches Elton read the lyrics as Sheila go on.

dialogues.speaker: SHEILA
dialogues.text: I want you out of here looking for a proper job. Do you have any idea what it takes to feed and clothe three grown men who are all of working age. It’s like a doss house around here and I’m the only one who does anything. You all just rely on me to take care of everything for you....

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I’d better go take a shave. Elton in a bit of a trance gets up and goes.

dialogues.speaker: 72A
dialogues.text: Bernie gets out his razor and foam and starts to shave. H hears Elton at the piano playing. It stops him from what is doing and he wanders out and down to: INT. LIVING ROOM, REGGIE’S HOUSE - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Bernie comes and stands in the door way as Elton composes Elton goes slowly but when he gets to the chorus he has gained a fluency of expression that just allows ‘Your Son to flow.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 43a.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: It’s a little bit funny, this feeling inside. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 74 75 White Shooting 44.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not one of those who can easily hide, I don’t have much money but boy, if I did. I’d buy a big house where we both could live. By the time he’s started the second verse, Bernie is in t doorway, listening. Elton now has the tune for the verse sings it brilliantly - Bernie’s lyrics are a platonic lov song to Elton but Elton’s emotional singing is directly t Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I was a sculptor but then again, no. Or a man who makes potions in a traveling show. Oh, I know it’s not much but it’s the best I can do. My gift is my song. And this one’s for you. Bernie stands stunned and moved. A life changing moment w something’s come together.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you can tell everybody this is your song. It may be quite simple but now that it’s done. I hope you don’t mind/ I hope you don’t mind. That I put down in words. How wonderful life is while you’re in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton plays ‘Your Song’. Engineers mesmerized and Ray is tears as the song finishes.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Was that alright?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: It was beautiful. INT. RAY WILLIAM’S OFFICE - DAY 75 Elton and Bernie sit on a large sofa. Dick James bursts i Ray Williams opens a bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: I love it! Best thing I’ve heard since ‘Let it be’. Trans-fucking- Atlantic. I always knew you could do it.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Our record sales are not exactly golden.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: No, they’re shit but people don’t know what they want until you tell them. Trust me. First off, I’m putting you on a three album deal!

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Three! ?

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: A year. And I’ve got you a few nights at the Troubadour. Doug Weston is an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Hang on! The Troubadour?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: It’s a really cool folk club in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: We know what it is!

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Let’s not be too hasty. I'll need a backing band.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: Ray, book some good session boys to play back up.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: Will do.

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: It’s time to do something bold! I’ve invested a ton of money into you boys.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Well, not really

dialogues.speaker: DICK
dialogues.text: The song is winner. At least it could be. Granted America’s a gamble and if you fuck it up I’1l kill you. Ray’1ll go too and keep and eye on you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 45A.

dialogues.speaker: DICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get yourself some new clothes, something flashy, put on a great fucking show and don’t kill yourself with drugs.  76 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 46. Elton looks worried but Bernie can hardly contain himself INT. MISS. DIRECTION SHOP —- DAY 76 Close on a winged platform boot that PETE the big, fat ow of the shop shows Elton and Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Is this the kind of thing you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I love them. I’1l1 take good care of them. Thanks for all this, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That’s alright. You can pay me back when you’re rich and famous. Bernie takes the shoe. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Can you even play the piano in those?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: These are extremely stylish boots of my own design. Very original.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You'll look like a tit.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I need to make an impact, Bernie. It’s America. It’s all about being cool. It’s going to be just me and a piano out there. It’s easy for you. This whole thing is a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Elton! You’1l be okay.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Come with me. This is where I keep all the really cool stuff. This is a whole new world man.  77 78 79 Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 47. Pete leads them to the back of the shop where all the wil wonderful and whacky things hang. The rails close in arou them.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. LINCOLN CONTINENTAL
dialogues.text: Close up of Elton and Bernie looking out the windows bemu We pull out to see they are actually in Los Angeles. Ray looks out at the palm trees and the beautiful girls and b of L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton, Bernie and Ray get out of the Lincoln in front of rundown old bar on Santa Monica Blvd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton, Bernie, Ray and the band look at the club. It is s and dark. A group of young women and men hang around by t bar. DOUG WESTON the owner greets them and shows them aro He is larger than life, wears a cowboy hat and has a larg Bowie knife on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Monday nights are always crazy here. It’s going to be packed later

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: It’s different from what I expected. A lot smaller.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Size is everything my friend. Neil Young was here last week and there were people around the block. Fantastic. The best night ever. Elton looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Cool hat.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I won it in a bet with Dave Crosby. Take it!

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Thanks... Doug sticks his hat on Bernie’s head.  80 81 White Shooting 48.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: If you want anything to drink the girls will take care of you. Hey Joni! Bernie looks over to the bar and a girl who looks a lot l JONI MITCHELL smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Give the guys whatever they want. They just flew in from England! Their arms are really tired. The girls all laugh at Doug’s lame joke. Doug puts his ar round Elton’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're stoked you’re here, man. Love the album - just love it. You're going to be great, man. Let me show you backstage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elton, Ray and the band all squashed into one tiny dressi room ready but excited. Elton is putting on the red jump suit, a sparkly bow tie and his first pair of platform sh with wings on the heals.

dialogues.speaker: BAND MEMBER
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, Elton what are you wearing? Elton turns round and in the mirror his name is written i sequins on the back of the red jumpsuit.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: My stage gear. Bernie rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Reg! Neil Diamond’s at the bar talking to Leon Russell and half the Beach Boys.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernie stands outside a cubicle door.  82 White Shooting 49.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You're over reacting. We hear Elton retch.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: They're the geniuses of American music. There is no way I’m going in front of that lot.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You can’t back out now! They’re all waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit. Suddenly Ray bursts in and busts open the cubicle door dragging Elton out.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: You've signed a contract and Dick has paid your fucking airfare - get out there and play you little bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of Elton in the half light at the side of the st He sweats, looks ill and terrified by the ordeal. The cam pushes in on him as we hear Doug.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And now ladies and gentlemen a rising star of Rock and Roll, all the way. From, London, England. Please welcome Elton John. Small applause. We follow Elton in slow motion as he goes stage. He looks out at the audience they seem a vast blur sits at the piano but freezes. A few people at the front at him but his eye moves to people who chat at the bar. H hears the glasses clink and the hot girls and boys who ch oblivious to him. He sits at the piano. The room goes qui We can hear him breathe and his heart pound. Suddenly he kicks the piano stool off the stage and launches into ‘CROCODILE ROCK’...

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I remember when I was young. Me and Suzie had so much fun. Holding hands and skimming stones. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Shooting 50.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Had an old gold Chevy and a place of my own. But the biggest kick I ever got. Was doing a thing called the Crocodile rock. While the other kids were rocking round the clock. We were hopping and bopping to the Crocodile Rock. Elton leaps about as he plays with electrifying abandon. ‘hot girls’ look on in wonder - Bernie slides up to them. Elton gives the performance of a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well Crocodile rocking is something shocking. When your feet just can’t keep still. I never knew me a better time and I guess I never will. Oh Lawdy mama those Friday nights. When Suzie wore her dresses tight. And the Crocodile rocking was out of sight. Elton and the piano slowly rise off the ground. He is suspended in the air by two feet as he plays. The audienc starts to rise up as well. Everyone joins in.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON/EVERYONE
dialogues.text: La lalalala la lalalala la lalala The whole energy and power of the music and performance i lifting everyone up and everything into the air. People a suspended and enthralled at what they are witnessing and Elton plays on unaware of the affect his show is having. is lost in the moment. He repeats a phrase again and agai the whole club floats up as one. He encourages them to jo in and drives the crowd to wilder and wilder appreciation Finally, he ends on a huge note and they all hang suspend in time and mid air in silence. For a split second he loo out to the stunned air born crowd. He sees Bernie who has huge grin on his face. The audience are elated and stunne and all smile at him.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Good grief! Elton smiles back then suddenly he remembers where he is everyone drops back down to the ground and spontaneously burst into a huge cheer and applause.  83 84 85 White Shooting 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insanity back stage after the gig. People crowd in to talk to Elton. Bernie bursts in on an elated and excited Elton.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You did it, Reg! You were brilliant! Elton hugs Bernie and sees he’s with one of the hot girls HEATHER. He is crestfallen as he knows what it means.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Elton. This is Heather. Heather grabs Bernie’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: You were amazing. Absolutely amazing. I love your boots.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: I’m not sure they’d suit you. Bernie looks embarrassed for a moment until Ray bursts in with Doug.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Okay, enough bullshit! Who wants to go to a party at Mama Cass’s? Ray holds up some keys.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: This is brilliant. Doug’s just lent me his car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are all in an open top car together. Ray drives a young girl on his lap. Elton, Bernie and Heather and ar all excited and love it. I/E. MAMA CASS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 85 They pile out of the car. People mill about in the road a in the front garden.

dialogues.speaker: COOL DUDE
dialogues.text: Hey man! It’s Elton-fuckin-John. Far out.  Blue Rev. (07/31/18) White Shooting 52. People give Elton a lot of attention. The cool Dude leads them into the old villa that has tepees and hammocks in t garden and an overgrown woodland feel. Guitars are played round camp fires. A bare footed and bare breasted wonderl of dope, hippies and musicians. Heather takes a joint and feeds it to Bernie as they walk in to the party. It is ro god heaven. INT. MAMA CASS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 86 Elton sits on a huge sofa between his heroes Leon Russell Mama Cass who smokes a big joint which she passes to Elto It’s relaxed and cool. A stoned and merry Bernie comes up whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Hey Elton. How cool is this?

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, great. Apparently, Dylan is here somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Good, good. Look, I’m going to disappear with Heather for a bit. Elton looks over at Heather as she gets some dope from th Cool Dude.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Really? Right...Er, okay.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: You'll be alright won’t you? Elton looks around the party. It’s a cool scene that he’s really a part of.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Yeah, course. We still going to Tower records? A distracted Bernie is smiling at Heather.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: She's talking about going to somewhere called Paradise Cove tomorrow. We’1ll go another time. Elton looks over at Heather. She smiles and waves. Heartbroken, Elton can see that Bernie is smitten.  87 88 89 90 White Shooting 53.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: She's really cool. So beautiful. America, man. Wide open spaces. Beautiful girls. It’s a dream come true. Let’s stay forever. Elton watches Bernie go to Heather as she kisses him and leads him off. Elton watches Bernie and Heather go into t garden.

dialogues.speaker: ELTON
